div.p: Most young criminals commit their first crime while they are teenagers and generally do so because they arethey're seeking excitement, or because they are following the example of older friends. I am convinced that sending these young peoplekids to prison is a counter-productiveuseless way of combating crime, and there are loadsa number of reasons why I believe they should not be imprisonedwe should not imprison them.

The main reason is that the majority of young people who break the law do so because of their upbringing or social circumstances. For example, they may come from deprived families, or live in run-down areas that already have a high crime ratelot of crime. Prison is highly unlikely to get to the bottom ofsolve their problems. What these first-time offenders need is to be supervised by qualified and skilled professionals, who can guide them away from a life of crime. This is best achievedpulled off by such means as youth centres and a system of probation or community service rather than by imprisonment.

A further reason is that being imprisoned is an extremelya really unpleasant experience and one which is likelysure to alienate young people even further, with the result that, when they havethey've served their sentence, they go offleave with a grudge against society and a desire for revengeto get their own back. Moreover, prisons do notdon't prepare young offenders to live as law-abiding citizens on their release. On the contrary, they serve as 'universities of crime', where young delinquents acquirepick up skills from experienced criminals. Not surprisinglySo of course, young criminals who have served a prison sentencedone time are more likely to re-offend than those who haven'thave not.

A final reason is that prison isprison's a waste of young people's time, at an age when they should either be continuinggetting on with their education or training for a job, the two activities which are most likely to steer them away from criminality.

In conclusionAt the end of the day, except in cases where they constitute a danger to society, I strongly believe that young first-time offenders should not receive prison sentences since imprisonment only increases the likelihood of their embarking on a career in crime. In my opinionIf you ask me, they should be rehabilitated and encouraged to lead constructive lives rather than be punished.

section.p: they're: You should avoid using contracted forms like this in your answers. They are too informal.
When you want to refer to society in general, it's best to use the passive voice instead of general subject pronouns such as 'they' or 'we'.
lots of crime: This isn't particular informal, and you wouldn't be marked down for using it, but the alternative here is better.
get to the bottom of: If you can, avoid colloquial expressions like this in your answers. Marks are given for appropriate style rather than colourful language.
pulled off: It's best to avoid using phrasal verbs like this if you can. If there is a single word equivalent, it is usually more formal and appropriate in style.
'Really' before an adjective, meaning very, is common in spoken English, but looks far too informal in a composition like this.

body.section: In Writing Task 2 you are expected to write in a fairly formal style. In practice this means that you should: - avoid the use of phrasal verbs,- avoid the use of idioms and colloquial words and phrases,- avoid the use of informal intensifiers such as 'really',- use more formal equivalents of phrasal verbs, idioms, colloquialisms and intensifiers,- use full forms rather than contractions (e.g. 'it is' not it's'),- use passive voice more extensively (but not continually).
